etymologies: Middle English: perhaps from lower + the frequentative suffix -k (as in talk). The noun is from British slang lurk ‘method of fraud’

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of place

definitions: (of a person or animal) be or remain hidden so as to wait in ambush for someone or something

examples.text: a ruthless killer still lurked in the darkness

definitions: (of an unpleasant quality) be present in a latent or barely discernible state, although still presenting a threat
shortDefinitions: (of unpleasant quality) remain in latent state

definitions: read the postings in an internet forum without actively contributing.
shortDefinitions: read postings in internet forum without actively contributing
